The Project is located in Gansu Province and involves the construction of 
the 98-megawatt (MW) run-of-river Xiaogushan Hydropower Plant (XHP) 
by  the  Xiaogushan  Hydropower  Company  (XHC);  upgrading  power 
supply  to  three  poor  townships  (Xishui,  Huazhai,  and  Anyang)  for  more 
reliable electricity directly from XHP; and institutional strengthening of  the 
project implementing agency.  
 
Coal-fired thermal power plants are the main source of energy in Gansu 
Province,  a  poor  inland  western  province.  The  capital,  Lanzhou,  has 
frequently been cited as one of the cities with the worst air pollution in the 
PRC, mainly arising from coal combustion and desertification. Gansu is in 
the  process  of  developing  several  needed  clean  energy  development 
initiatives,  covering  a  spectrum  of  renewable  energy  technologies. 
However,  clean  energy  production  is  unevenly  distributed  and  faces 
many challenges in Gansu. 
 
Zhangye City is a poor area of Gansu with a deficient energy supply. Of 
Zhangye City’s 1.25 million population, almost 80% are classified as rural. 
Of its rural population, 293,000 or about 23% have incomes less than the 
provincial rural poverty line. Using the lower range of provincial estimates, 
17,000 persons in Zhangye City can be classified as urban poor. Located 
about  600  kilometers  northwest  from  the  provincial  capital  of  Lanzhou, 
the  City  experiences  frequent  interruptions  and  shortages  in  electricity 
supply.  The  Zhangye  City  electric  network  is  part  of  the  Hexi  corridor 
network,  which  in  turn  is  part  of  the  Gansu  and  Northwest  power 
networks.  
 
The installed capacity in Zhangye City and in the Hexi grid is too small to 
meet  the  current  peak  load demand and most of the power stations are 
small. In 2001, the Zhangye network experienced load-shedding of 1,975 
hours,  equivalent  to  3.2  gigawatt-hours  (GWh)  of  unserved  energy 
demand. The current installed capacity in Zhangye City is approximately 
94.5 MW,  whereas  peak  demand  is  almost  200 MW.  The  Hexi  corridor 
grid  has  installed  capacity  of  475 MW  against  its  peak  demand  of 
850 MW.  Zhangye  City  is  importing  more  than  80%  of  its  electricity 
demand  of  about  900  GWh  from  the  Hexi  corridor  network. The power 
situation  in  Zhangye  City  is  expected  to  become  worse  as  projected 
electricity  demand  is  increasing  but  no  new  generating  plants  are 
expected to become operational until 2006. The power shortage is a key

development  in  Zhangye  City  by  providing  reliable  electricity  supply  to 
local  agriculture  and  cottage  industries,  and  to  reinforce  the  power 
availability and reliability in the electricity grid. 
 
The  main  objective  of  the  Project  is  to  contribute  to  environmental 
improvement  in  Zhangye  City  through  provision  of  improved  access  to

river  hydropower  plant,  (ii)  rural  electrification,  and  (iii)  institutional

The financial internal rate of return (FIRR) of the Project is 7.5%, which is 
higher than the weighted average cost of capital of 4.5%. The  economic 
internal rate of return (EIRR) is 23.4%. Sensitivity tests show that both the 
FIRR  and  EIRR  will  be  able  to  withstand  reasonable  changes  in 
assumptions. 
 
XHP will have several types of risks, including geotechnical, hydrological, 
and financial risks. XHC is aware of these risks and adequate steps are 
being  taken  to  avoid  or  minimize  them.  It  has obtained a license to use 
the river for the operations of XHP. Additional intangible risks exist due to 
the ongoing restructuring of the power sector.  
 
Sensitivity  analysis  has  been  conducted  to  investigate  the  effects  of 
changes in key variables on the financial and economic viability of XHC, 
compared  with  the  base  case.  Only  adverse  changes  are  considered. 
Both  financial  and  economic  indicators  remain  robust  despite  simulated 
adverse  conditions.  Risk  analyses  have  also  been  performed  using  a 
probabilistic  approach  to  the  perceived  risk  factors  that  affect  the 
economic  viability  of  XHC.  Based  on  the  weighted  average  of  all 
simulated  combinations,  the  expected  EIRR  is  well  within  acceptable 
levels.

2. 
Economic and social development in PRC has been rapid in the last two decades.  The 
PRC’s gross domestic product (GDP) per capita was $964 (in 2002 values), life expectancy at 
birth  is  70.1  years,  and  adult  literacy  is  83%.  Government  programs  have  resulted  in  poverty 
reduction, particularly in rural areas. Using the official rural poverty line of CNY947 per capita, 
the PRC’s rural poor represents  4.6% of the rural population. Studies estimate urban poverty in 
the PRC at 4.7%. 
 
3. 
Economic  growth  has  been  facilitated  by  infrastructure  development,  a  crucial 
component  being  energy  sector  development.  At  the  end  of  2002,  the  PRC’s  total  installed 
power was 350 gigawatts (GW). By 2010, it is estimated that total installed capacity will reach 
450 GW.  The  PRC's  electricity  is  generated  overwhelmingly  by  coal  (about  75%).  Coal  use  in 
the  PRC  entails  high  transport  costs  and  is  characterized  by  low  utilization  efficiency. 
Hydroelectricity  ranks  a  distant  second  (about  20%),  followed  by  oil,  gas,  and  nuclear  power, 
which  account  for  the  remaining  5%.  Appendix  2  gives  a  summary  analysis  for  the  energy 
sector.  
 
4. 
The  heavy  dependence  on  coal  as  an  energy  source  has  resulted  in  substantial 
environmental  damage  due  to  pollution.  The  adverse  impacts  of  environmental  pollution  have 
been  acknowledged  to  disproportionately  affect  the  poor.  Poorer  households  typically  rely  on 
raw  coal  and  biomass  (e.g.,  wood  and  animal  dung)  for  cooking  and  heating,  and  suffer 
accordingly from indoor air pollution. High pollution loads and energy intensity would be reduced 
if there were a more pronounced shift toward clean energy, energy efficiency, and greenhouse 
gas abatement.  
 
5.  
Coal-fired  thermal  power  plants  are  the  main  source  of  energy  in  Gansu  province; 
however,  hydropower  accounted  for  41%  of  power  generation  in  2000.  Gansu  is  developing 
several  clean  energy  development  initiatives,  covering  a  wide  spectrum  of  renewable  energy 
technologies. Installed wind generating capacity is 8 megawatts (MW). Residential solar water 
heaters are becoming more common. Solar photovoltaic and battery systems are used in some 
remote,  off-grid  areas  as  source  of  power  for  small  appliances  (e.g.,  radio  and  television).1 
Biomass-to-biogas  is  another  potential  source  of  clean  energy  for  agricultural  areas.  Different 
technologies have regional applications within the Province, with solar and wind appearing more 
promising  in  the  western  areas,  and  greater  hydropower  potential  in  the  southeastern  areas. 
Several small and medium-scale hydropower projects have been commissioned in the region of 
the  Project,  with  several  more  planned  for  development.  However,  clean  energy  production  is 
unevenly  distributed  in  Gansu.  The  capital,  Lanzhou,  has  frequently  been  cited  as  one  of  the 
cities  with  the  worst  air  pollution  in  the  PRC,  mainly  arising  from  coal  combustion  and 
desertification.

The  98 MW  Xiaogushan  hydropower  plant  (XHP)  is  the  least-cost  alternative  for 
generation expansion in Gansu province. XHP will represent about 38% of the installed capacity 
in the Zhangye grid and, in the short term, it is likely to dominate the local generation scene in 
terms of ancillary services, peak load, and base-load management. With only 98 MW installed 
capacity, however, it will not be able to influence the electricity generation tariffs in the electricity 
market.  To  ensure  the  ongoing  financial  viability  of  the  operations  of  the  Xiaogushan 
Hydropower Company (XHC) in the future, it is necessary to ensure that the overall operation of 
XHC  is  competitive  and  that  its  management  is  well  equipped  to  maximize  the  value  of  its 
natural advantages—lower transmission losses as it is close to the local load center and overall 
low-cost  operation  as  a  small  run-of-river  hydropower  station.  XHC  and  the  Gansu  provincial 
government  (GPG)  need  to  ensure  that  the  framework  for  competition  and  regulation  is 
effective,  transparent,  and  predictable.  This  is  to  ensure  a  free  and  fair  competitive market for 
generation in the province.

Economic and Financial Viability 

1. 

Demand Analysis 

 
51. 
The load forecast period for the Gansu network was divided into two terms: short-term 
(3 years)  and  long-term  (to  the  end  of  the  system  planning  period  in  2020).  A  bottom-up 
approach or  sector  analysis method  was  used  for  the  short-term  forecast.  Different  end-use 
demands—primary  (agriculture),  secondary  (industry  and  construction),  tertiary  (including 
commercial and  service), and residential  (urban  and  rural)—were calculated based on current 
economic  activities,  policies,  and  impact  of  recent  major  construction  projects  in  Gansu 
province.  Three  methods—regression,  linear  time  series,  and  exponential  time  series—were 
used  for  forecasting  energy  consumption.  The  regression  model  used  electricity  tariff,  gross 
domestic  product,  population,  industry  structure,  and  energy  efficiency  as  independent 
variables. The historical data from 1986 to 2001 and the short-term demand information (2002–
2004) were all taken as inputs to the regression model. The estimates of the exponential time 
series  (GWh 89,788)  and  regression  models  (GWh 90,083)  were  similar,  whereas  the  linear 
time  series  produced  a  different  trend.  The  analysis  used  the  estimate  from  the  regression 
model  and  rejected  the  results  from  the  linear  time  series  (Appendix  13  and  Supplementary 
Appendix J).  
 

2. 

Least-Cost Analysis 

 
Because  of  the  large  gap  between  demand  (1,400–2,000 GWh)  and  supply  (750–
52. 
1,200 GWh) in Zhangye City, demand-side responses were not considered as full alternatives in 
the  analysis.  Only  supply-side  options—new  generation  plants—were used as viable options. 
Five initial alternatives using  three power generation technologies—hydropower, coal-fired, and 
natural-gas-fired—were preliminarily considered for selecting viable electricity generation for the 
province. Three fossil fuel generation technologies were considered as technology alternatives: 
coal-fired thermal (small 300 MW and large 600 MW), and combined-cycle gas turbine (CCGT 
300 MW). Technology alternatives, including XHP, were analyzed in detail. Capital and annual 
operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  costs  for  each  technology  alternative  were  examined.  The 
hydropower and coal-fired power stations were the only two options that showed a positive net 
present value (using a 12% discount rate). The larger hydropower option was not considered in 
detail due to project schedule and hydrologic restrictions; the CCGT option was dropped due to 
the lack of natural gas in the project area. 
 
53. 
For  direct  comparability,  the  output  of  each  alternative  was  normalized.  Adjustments 
were  also  made  for  load  factor  differences.  It  was  assumed  that  aside  from  the  benefit  for 
capacity  substitution  for  XHC,  the  alternatives  would  generate  more  energy  (the  load factor is 
around 68%) to substitute generation from small  coal-fired plants. The latter could not be used 
to  meet  incremental  demand,  but  would  save  fuel  consumption  in  existing  plants,  bringing 

  

15

energy savings benefits.  The  equalizing  discount  rate—the  rate  at  which  the  present  value  of 
two  life-cycle  cost  streams  are  equal—thus  indicating  a  discount  rate  at  which  preference 
changes—shows  that  hydropower  remains  a  better  alternative  up  to  the  discount  rate  of 
12.85%, after which smaller thermal power  units  will  be  preferable.  Hydropower,  with  its  high 
capital costs and very low operational costs, is the preferred option when lower discount rates 
are used (Appendix 13).  
 
54. 
Using viable technological options—hydropower and coal-fired  plants—a list of feasible 
power plant alternatives was developed, subject to the constraints imposed by the environment, 
river flow, and geography/geology. Various hydropower candidates were considered (including 
few-MW  small  hydropower  stations  up  to  large  stations  such  as  the  1,400  MW  Heishanxia 
station).  The  development  sequence  for  these  hydropower  candidates  before  2010  has  been 
designated as  “fixed  scheme”,  because  either  they are  under construction or  there have  been 
other  development  purposes  (flood  control  and  water  supply).  XHP  is  the  only  candidate  for 
power expansion in the period up to 2010 and others, except fixed ones, will be available after 
2010.  
 
55. 
The  Generation  Expansion  System  Planning  (GESP)  II  model  developed  by  Power 
Economic  Research  Institute  of  Beijing  was  used  to  identify  the  least-cost alternative generation 
option  from  the  list  of  feasible  alternatives  based  on  the  demand forecast for  the  Gansu power 
system. The least-cost analyses confirmed the robustness of XHP. The GESP II model optimized the 
objective function of minimum total system cost—capital costs, operational costs, and other external 
costs—to meet power demand within the defined reliability criteria. The planning period used was 
2002 to 2020 and, in order to reflect the operation characteristics of expansion candidates sufficiently, 
the study period was expanded to 2050. The technical and economic indices of the power system 
from 2021 to 2050 were assumed to be same with those in 2020. 
 
56. 
Three hydrologic conditions were considered: average with 80% probability, wet with 10% 
probability, and dry with 10% probability. The production simulation was carried out for all hydrologic 
conditions.  The  least-cost  analysis  used  the  weighted  average  operations  cost  based  on  the 
probabilities  in  the  objective  function.  The  forecast  annual  load  curve  was  modeled  using  three 
seasons: wet season (April to September), average season (October to December), and dry season 
(January to March). Based on historic data, the system peak was modeled in the dry season. The 
fixed  system  included  existing  power  plants   (under  construction  or  decided  generation  plants, 
retirement  plans  of  generation  units,  and  power  exchanges  with  other  power  grids.  The GESP 
model  identified  the  98 MW  (351  GWh)  XHP  as  the  least-cost  alternative  for  generation 
expansion in Gansu province (Appendix 13).

1. 
Project construction will have minor and very localized impacts on two villages in Xishui 
township. The population of Xishui township is only 1,151 despite a large administrative area of 
894 square kilometers. Farmland is very limited so people earn their livelihood as herders. The 
Project will permanently occupy 28 hectares (ha) of land, most of which is wasteland and about 
10  ha  is  grassland.  Only  two  households  (17 persons)  will  be  affected  by  permanent loss of 
grassland  rights,  animal  sheds,  or  trees,  for  which  compensation  has  already  been  paid.  The 
Project  will  also  temporarily  occupy  26.7  ha  (mostly  wasteland  and  some  grassland)  for 
construction camps, borrow areas, spoil areas, and temporary work areas. Four households (12 
persons) will be compensated for temporary losses. In total, only 100 square meters of animal 
sheds will be affected; no residential structures need to be relocated. Since the Project is a run-
of-river  hydropower  plant,  components  that  affect  people  are  the  powerhouse  site  and  the

A  short  resettlement  plan  (RP)  has  been  prepared  by  the  Xiaogushan  Hydropower 
Company  (XHC)  (Supplementary  Appendix  G).  The  RP  is  based  on  the  preliminary  design

1. 
Energy demand forecasts play a key role in generation planning since the level of future 
demand is one of the critical variables in selecting the least-cost power plant. The load forecast

time  series—were  used  for  forecasting  energy  consumption.  The  regression  model  used

The planning period used was 2002 to 2020 and in order to reflect the operation characteristics 
of expansion candidates sufficiently, the study period was expanded to 2050. The technical and 
economic  indices  of  the  power  system  from  2021  to  2050  were  assumed  to  be  the  same  as

The optimization model simulated power exchange between Gansu and other provinces

with  10%  probability.  The  production  simulation was carried out for all hydrological conditions. 
The least-cost analysis used the weighted average operations cost based on the probabilities in 
the objective function. The forecast annual load curve was modeled using three seasons: wet 
season (April to September), average season (October to  December), and dry season (January 
to  March).  Based  on  the  historic  data,  the  system  peak  was  modeled  in  the  dry  season.  The 
fixed  system  included  existing  power  plants,  under  construction  or  decided  generation  plants, 
retirement  plan  of  generation  units,  and  power  exchanges  with  other  power  grids.  The GESP

SOCIAL AND POVERTY ANALYSIS 

Poverty Analysis  

 
A. 
 
1. 
Poverty Profile of Project Area. Of Zhangye City’s 1.25 million population, almost 80% 
are  classified  as  rural.  Of  its  rural  population,  293,000  or  almost  30%  have  incomes  less than 
the  national  rural  poverty  line  of  CNY1,100.  Using  the  lower  range  of  provincial  estimates  it  is 
estimated  that  17,000  can  be  classified  as  poor.  Details  of  poverty  incidence  in  Zhangye  City 
can be found in Supplementary Appendix N.  
 
2. 
Causes of Poverty. In the farming areas of  Zhangye City, the main causes of poverty 
are related to low farm productivity, lack of supplemental income sources, and lack of education. 
This  is  aside  from  the  harsh  natural  conditions,  which  includes  high altitude  that  limits the 
growing season to 80–170 frost-free days allowing only one field crop per year; poor soils and 
low  rainfall;  and  inadequate  irrigation.  Many  farmers  have  unreliable  gravity  irrigation  and 
cannot  use  electricity  to  pump  water  from  either  an  irrigation  canal  or  from  an  aquifer  of 
economic  depth  resulting  in  lower  and  less  stable  yields.  Herder  communities  face  similar 
issues of low productivity, lack of supplemental income sources, and lack of education.  
 
3. 
Rural Electricity Services and Household Consumption. Rural areas in Zhangye City 
face  regular  load  shedding.  During  power  shortages,  remote  rural  areas,  which  are  generally 
serviced through 10-kilovolt distribution lines, are cut off first. Xishui township, where the project 
is  located,  had  power  outages  for  70  days  in  2001  due  to  load  shedding.  The  power  outages 
generally  last  one  or  two  days.  Outages  result  in  electricity  being  unavailable  during  critical 
periods  of  the  growing  season,  according  to  farmers.  Low  voltages  prevent  the  usage  of 
sensitive  appliances,  motors,  and  equipment  (e.g.,  x-ray machines in clinics) or may damage 
equipment due to voltage fluctuations. Extra cost is required for voltage stabilizers. The average 
electricity consumption of poor households is generally very low. 
 
B. 
 
4. 
Ethnic Minorities There are 32 ethnic minorities in Zhangye City accounting for 2.1% of 
Zhangye’s  total  population.  The  largest  groups  are  Yugur  (37.1%),  Zang/Tibetan  (36.6%),  and 
Hui (15.9%), with the rest of the minorities constituting less than 10% of the total. Three-fourths 
of  ethnic  minorities in  Zhangye  City  are  in  Sunan,  the  only  Yugur  autonomous  county  in  the 
People’s  Republic  of  China.  The  nationalities  directly  affected  by  the  project  are  the  Zang  in 
Mati district and the Yugur in neighboring districts, all located in Sunan county. The Xiaogushan 
Hydropower  Plant  construction  will  have  very  localized  impacts  on  two  villages  in  Xishui.  The 
local  community  will  benefit  economically  from  its  proximity  to  the  construction  activities  and
